ai-mn32:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Gosiṅga called Sal Wood. He was a number of well-known senior disciples, together with several well-known senior disciples, such as
ai-mn32:1.3_0: the venerables Sāriputta, Mahāmoggallāna, Mahākassapa, Anuruddha, Revata, Ānanda, and others.
ai-mn32:2.1_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna came out of retreat, went to Venerable Mahākassapa,
ai-mn32:2.1_1: and after going, he said this to venerable Mahākassapa:
ai-mn32:2.2_0: “Come, Reverend Kassapa, let’s go to Venerable Sāriputta to hear the teaching.”
ai-mn32:2.4_0: Then, together with Venerable Anuruddha, they went to Sāriputta to hear the teaching.
ai-mn32:3.2_0: went to Venerable Revata, told him what was happening,
ai-mn32:3.4_0: Come, reverend, let’s go to Venerable Sāriputta to hear the teaching.”
ai-mn32:3.6_0: Then, together with Venerable Ānanda went to Venerable Sāriputta to hear the teaching.
ai-mn32:4.1_0: Sāriputta saw them coming off in the distance
ai-mn32:4.4_0: Welcome to Ānanda, the Buddha’s attendant, who is so close to the Buddha.
ai-mn32:4.5_0: Ānanda, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air.
ai-mn32:4.6_0: What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?”
ai-mn32:4.7_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned.
ai-mn32:4.7_1: and those Dhamma teachings that are good in the beginning, good in the middle, good in the end, with the right meaning, and good in the end,
ai-mn32:4.7_2: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s totally full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
ai-mn32:4.8_0: And they teach the four assemblies in order to uproot the underlying tendencies with well-rounded and systematic words and phrases.
ai-mn32:4.9_0: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”
ai-mn32:5.1_0: When he had spoken, Sāriputta said to Revata,
ai-mn32:5.2_0: “Reverend Revata, Ānanda has answered by speaking from his heart.
ai-mn32:5.3_0: And now we ask you the same question.”
ai-mn32:5.4_0: Sāriputta, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air.
ai-mn32:5.5_0: What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?”
ai-mn32:5.6_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who enjoys retreat and loves retreat. They’re committed to inner serenity of the heart, they don’t neglect absorption, they’re endowed with discernment, and they frequent empty huts.
ai-mn32:5.7_0: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”
ai-mn32:6.1_0: When he had spoken, Sāriputta said to Anuruddha,
ai-mn32:6.2_0: “Reverend Anuruddha, Revata has answered by speaking from his heart.
ai-mn32:6.3_0: And now we ask you the same question.”
ai-mn32:6.4_0: Sāriputta, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air.
ai-mn32:6.5_0: What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?”
ai-mn32:6.6_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who surveys the entire galaxy with clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human,
ai-mn32:6.7_0: just as a person with good sight could survey a thousand wheel rims from the upper floor of a stilt longhouse.
ai-mn32:6.8_0: In the same way, with clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human ...
ai-mn32:6.9_0: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”
ai-mn32:7.1_0: When he said this, Venerable Sāriputta said to him,
ai-mn32:7.2_0: “Reverend Kassapa, Anuruddha has answered by speaking from his heart.
ai-mn32:7.3_0: And now we ask you the same question.”
ai-mn32:7.4_0: Sāriputta, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air.
ai-mn32:7.5_0: What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?”
ai-mn32:7.6_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who lives in the wilderness, eats only alms-food, wears rag robes, and owns just three robes; and they praise these things. They are of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, and energetic; and they praise these things. They are accomplished in ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom; and they praise these things.
ai-mn32:7.7_0: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”
ai-mn32:8.1_0: When he said this, Sāriputta said to Mahāmoggallāna,
ai-mn32:8.2_0: “Reverend Moggallāna, Mahākassapa has answered by speaking from his heart.
ai-mn32:8.3_0: And now we ask you the same question.”
ai-mn32:8.4_0: ‘Reverend Moggallāna, this is lovely, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air.
ai-mn32:8.5_0: What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?”
ai-mn32:8.6_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s when two mendicants engage in discussion about the teaching ...
ai-mn32:8.7_0: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”
ai-mn32:9.2_0: “Each of us has spoken from our heart.
ai-mn32:9.4_0: Sāriputta, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air.
ai-mn32:9.5_0: What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?”
ai-mn32:9.6_0: “Reverend Moggallāna, it’s when a mendicant masters their mind and is not mastered by it.
ai-mn32:9.7_0: In the morning, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want.
ai-mn32:9.9_0: and in the evening, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want.
ai-mn32:9.10_0: Suppose that a ruler or their minister had a chest full of garments of different colors.
ai-mn32:9.11_0: In the morning, they’d don whatever pair of garments they wanted.
ai-mn32:9.13_0: and in the evening, they’d don whatever pair of garments they wanted.
ai-mn32:9.14_0: In the same way, a mendicant masters their mind and is not mastered by it.
ai-mn32:9.15_0: In the morning, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want.
ai-mn32:9.17_0: and in the evening, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want.
ai-mn32:9.18_0: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”
ai-mn32:10.1_0: Then Sāriputta said to those venerables,
ai-mn32:10.2_0: “Each of us has spoken from the heart.
ai-mn32:10.3_0: Come, reverends, let’s go to the Buddha, and tell him about this.
ai-mn32:10.4_0: As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”
ai-mn32:10.6_0: Then those venerables went to the Fortunate One,
ai-mn32:10.6_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-mn32:10.6_2: While sitting on one side venerable Sāriputta said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-mn32:11.1_0: “Here, sir, and Venerable Ānanda were going to listen to the teaching.
ai-mn32:11.2_0: Seeing them coming off in the distance
ai-mn32:11.5_0: Welcome to Ānanda, the Buddha’s attendant, who is so close to the Buddha.
ai-mn32:11.6_0: Ānanda, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air.
ai-mn32:11.7_0: What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?’
ai-mn32:11.8_0: When I had spoken, Ānanda said to me:
ai-mn32:11.9_0: ‘Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who is very learned ...
ai-mn32:11.11_0: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.’”
ai-mn32:11.13_0: Ānanda answered in the right way for him.
ai-mn32:11.14_1: and those Dhamma teachings that are good in the beginning, good in the middle, good in the end, with the right meaning, and good in the end,
ai-mn32:11.14_2: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s totally full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
ai-mn32:11.15_0: And they teach the four assemblies in order to uproot the underlying tendencies with well-rounded and systematic words and phrases.”
ai-mn32:12.1_0: “Next I asked Revata the same question.
ai-mn32:12.2_0: ‘Reverend Revata, Ānanda has answered by speaking from his heart.
ai-mn32:12.3_0: And now we ask you the same question.”
ai-mn32:12.4_0: “‘Upāli, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air.
ai-mn32:12.5_0: What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?’
ai-mn32:12.6_0: When he had spoken, Revata said to me:
ai-mn32:12.8_0: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.’”
ai-mn32:12.10_0: Revata answered in the right way for him.
ai-mn32:12.11_0: For someone Revata enjoys retreat and loves retreat. They’re committed to inner serenity of the heart, they don’t neglect absorption, they’re endowed with discernment, and they frequent empty huts.”
ai-mn32:13.1_0: “Next I asked Anuruddha the same question.
ai-mn32:13.2_0: ‘Reverend Anuruddha, Revata has answered by speaking from his heart. ...
ai-mn32:13.3_0: What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?’
ai-mn32:13.4_0: When I had spoken, Anuruddha said to me:
ai-mn32:13.5_0: ‘It’s a mendicant who surveys the entire galaxy with clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human ...
ai-mn32:13.6_0: Suppose there was a person with good eyesight. They’re like a person who regards the eye ...
ai-mn32:13.7_0: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.’”
ai-mn32:13.8_0: “Good, good, Sāriputta! Anuruddha answered in the right way for him.
ai-mn32:13.9_0: For it is with clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human, that is purified and surpasses the human ...”
ai-mn32:14.1_0: “Next I asked Mahākassapa the same question.
ai-mn32:14.2_0: ‘Reverend Kassapa, Anuruddha has answered by speaking from his heart.
ai-mn32:14.3_0: And now we ask you the same question.”
ai-mn32:14.4_0: What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?’
ai-mn32:14.5_0: When I had spoken, Venerable Mahākassapa said to me:
ai-mn32:14.6_0: ‘It’s a mendicant who lives in the wilderness, and praises these things.
ai-mn32:14.6_12: They’re personally accomplished in the knowledge and vision of freedom, and praises such freedom.
ai-mn32:14.7_0: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.’”
ai-mn32:14.9_0: Kassapa answered in the right way for him.
ai-mn32:14.10_0: Kassapa is the one who lives in the wilderness, eats only alms-food, wears rag robes, and owns just three robes; and they praise these things. They are of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, and energetic; and they praise these things.”
ai-mn32:15.1_0: “Next I asked Mahāmoggallāna the same question.
ai-mn32:15.2_0: ‘Reverend Moggallāna, Mahākassapa has answered by speaking from his heart.
ai-mn32:15.3_0: And now we ask you the same question.”
ai-mn32:15.4_0: What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?’
ai-mn32:15.5_0: When I said this, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said to me:
ai-mn32:15.6_0: ‘It’s when two mendicants engage in discussion about the teaching.
ai-mn32:15.7_0: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.’”
ai-mn32:15.8_0: “Good, good, Sāriputta! Moggallāna answered in the right way for him.
ai-mn32:15.9_0: For Moggallāna is a Dhamma speaker.”
ai-mn32:16.1_0: When he said this, Venerable Moggallāna asked the Buddha,
ai-mn32:16.3_0: ‘Each of us has spoken from our heart.
ai-mn32:16.5_0: Sāriputta, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air.
ai-mn32:16.6_0: What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?’
ai-mn32:16.7_0: When I had spoken, Sāriputta said to me:
ai-mn32:16.8_0: ‘It’s when a mendicant masters their mind and is not mastered by it.
ai-mn32:16.9_0: In the morning, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want.
ai-mn32:16.11_0: and in the evening, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want.
ai-mn32:16.12_0: Suppose that a ruler or their minister had a chest full of garments of different colors.
ai-mn32:16.13_0: In the morning, they’d don whatever pair of garments they wanted.
ai-mn32:16.15_0: and in the evening, they’d don whatever pair of garments they wanted.
ai-mn32:16.16_0: In the same way, a mendicant masters their mind and is not mastered by it.
ai-mn32:16.17_0: In the morning, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want.
ai-mn32:16.19_0: and in the evening, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want.
ai-mn32:16.20_0: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.’”
ai-mn32:16.22_0: Sāriputta answered in the right way for him.
ai-mn32:16.23_0: For Sāriputta masters his mind and is not mastered by it ...”
ai-mn32:16.24_0: In the morning, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want.
ai-mn32:16.26_0: and in the evening, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want.”
ai-mn32:17.1_0: When he said this, Venerable Sāriputta said to the Buddha,
ai-mn32:17.3_0: “You’ve all spoken well in your own way.
ai-mn32:17.4_0: However, listen to me also as to what kind of mendicant would beautify this sal forest park at Gosiṅga.
ai-mn32:17.5_0: It’s a mendicant who, after the meal, returns from alms-round, sits down cross-legged with their body straight, and establishes mindfulness right there, thinking:
ai-mn32:17.6_0: ‘I will not break this sitting posture until my mind is freed from the defilements by not grasping!’
ai-mn32:17.7_0: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”
ai-mn32:17.8_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn32:17.9_0: Satisfied, those venerables were happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-mn32:17.10_0: The Long Discourse at Gosiṅga is finished.
